<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 220, 321]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 388, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 1 (S1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 910, 571]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 598, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 608, 630]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 757, 675]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 675, 440, 690]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
Jameel has 5 plums and 3 apricots in a box. Rosa has \(x\) plums and 6 apricots in a box. One fruit is chosen at random from Jameel's box and one fruit is chosen at random from Rosa's box. The probability that both fruits chosen are plums is \(\frac{1}{4}\). Write down an equation in \(x\) and hence find \(x\). [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A fair six-sided die is thrown twice and the scores are noted. Event \(X\) is defined as ‘The total of the two scores is 4’. Event \(Y\) is defined as ‘The first score is 2 or 5’. Are events \(X\) and \(Y\) independent? Justify your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The Mathematics and English A-level marks of 1400 pupils all taking the same examinations are shown in the cumulative frequency graphs below. Both examinations are marked out of 100.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 133, 816, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Use suitable data from these graphs to compare the central tendency and spread of the marks in Mathematics and English.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 675, 92]]<|/det|>
In a certain country the probability that a child owns a bicycle is 0.65.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 15 children from this country is chosen. Find the probability that more than 12 own a bicycle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 250 children from this country is chosen. Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that fewer than 179 own a bicycle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 908, 92]]<|/det|>
At a funfair, Amy pays $1 for two attempts to make a bell ring by shooting at it with a water pistol.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 98, 148, 116]]<|/det|>
<label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 97, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
If she makes the bell ring on her first attempt, she receives \(3 and stops playing. This means that overall she has gained\) 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 138, 148, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 136, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
If she makes the bell ring on her second attempt, she receives \(1.50 and stops playing. This means that overall she has gained\) 0.50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 175, 148, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 173, 811, 193]]<|/det|>
If she does not make the bell ring in the two attempts, she has lost her original \(1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 205, 920, 223]]<|/det|>
The probability that Amy makes the bell ring on any attempt is 0.2, independently of other attempts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 237, 151, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 237, 670, 255]]<|/det|>
Show that the probability that Amy loses her original \(1 is 0.64.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 237, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 910, 92]]<|/det|>
Freddie has 6 toy cars and 3 toy buses, all different. He chooses 4 toys to take on holiday with him.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 601, 123]]<|/det|>
In how many different ways can Freddie choose 4 toys?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 250, 153, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 250, 828, 268]]<|/det|>
How many of these choices will include both his favourite car and his favourite bus?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 250, 920, 268]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 428, 479]]<|/det|>
Freddie arranges these 9 toys in a line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 153, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 490, 796, 509]]<|/det|>
Find the number of possible arrangements if the buses are all next to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 529, 918, 547]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Find the number of possible arrangements if there is a car at each end of the line and no buses are next to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
